title: 109_hr477
content: The Act is titled the "Continuing Care for Recovering Families Act" and extends COBRA coverage for certain individuals. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 is amended to allow eligible individuals affected by terrorist attacks to elect continuation coverage under COBRA for 120 days from the date of enactment of the Continuing Care for Recovering Families Act or the date of loss of coverage. The 120-day election period for continuation coverage under COBRA starts at the terrorism-related loss of coverage and ends on the first day of the election period. The period before the 120-day election period is disregarded for determining certain timeframes. The term 'eligible individual' is defined as a child or spouse of a victim of the September 11th attacks who has experienced a terrorism-related loss of coverage and is not otherwise entitled to benefits. The term 'terrorism-related loss of coverage' refers to the loss of health benefits due to the death, injury, or loss of employment of an eligible individual as defined in the September 11th Victim Compensation Fund. This amendment extends the COBRA election and coverage period for victims of terrorist attacks under the Public Health Service Act. Victims of Terrorist Attacks can elect continuation coverage under the Continuing Care for Recovering Families Act for 120 days after experiencing a terrorism-related loss of coverage. The coverage starts at the beginning of the election period and does not include any prior period. The maximum period required for continuation coverage under the Continuing Care for Recovering Families Act shall not be less than the individual's eligibility period. Preexisting conditions are disregarded for determining specific periods during the election period. The term 'eligible individual' in this subsection refers to individuals who are children or spouses of those affected by the September 11th Victim Compensation Fund, have experienced a terrorism-related loss of coverage, and are not entitled to benefits under the Social Security Act. The term 'terrorism-related loss of coverage' refers to the loss of health benefits associated with the death, injury, or loss of employment of individuals eligible under the September 11th Victim Compensation Fund. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code include a temporary extension of COBRA election and coverage period for victims of terrorist attacks. An eligible individual can elect continuation coverage under this title within 120 days of the date of enactment of the Continuing Care for Recovering Families Act or the date of experiencing a terrorism-related loss of coverage. The maximum period for electing continuation coverage begins at the start of the 120-day election period and does not include any time before that. For individuals electing continuation coverage due to a terrorism-related loss of coverage, the period starts on the date of the loss and ends on the first day of coverage. The 120-day election period for continuation coverage disregards time before it starts for determining 63-day periods under various acts. Definitions include an eligible individual as a child. The individual must be a child or spouse of a 9/11 Victim Compensation Fund recipient, have experienced a terrorism-related loss of coverage, and not be covered elsewhere. The term 'terrorism-related loss of coverage' refers to the loss of health benefits due to the death, injury, or loss of employment of an eligible individual. The term 'terrorism-related loss of coverage' refers to the loss of health benefits due to the death, injury, or loss of employment of an eligible individual as defined in section 405(c)(2) of the September 11th Victim Compensation Fund of 2001.
